docs.lead_paragraph: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, a giant in American insurance and a civic and industrial power in New Jersey, plans to announce tomorrow that it is reorganizing its corporate structure so it can issue stock and join the ranks of publicly traded companies. For decades, Prudential has been formally owned by its policyholders and, in effect, run as a cooperative. Increasingly, companies of this type, known as mutuals, have decided they need the ability to issue stock to raise money for expansions and acquisitions.

headline.main: Prudential To Go Public And Sell Stock For First Time

docs.lead_paragraph: WE are like a mosaic, not a collection of entities,'' said Michael Dowling, chief operating officer of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System. ''Each piece has it own culture, its own beauty. When you put them together, you gain the beauty of the whole, much like the pieces of a church window. Each piece has its own characteristics, but the mission and values are the same and together you have a beautiful mosaic.'' Or a jumble of broken glass. But three years after their 1997 merger formed one of the largest health systems in the metro region, Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park and Manhasset-based North Shore Health System appear to have made a successful match.

headline.main: After Merger's Bumpy Start, North Shore-L.I.J. Is Clicking

docs.lead_paragraph: I WOULD have liked to have been a justice of the Supreme Court for one case, yes,'' Mario M. Cuomo said. ''It would have been this case.'' Mr. Cuomo -- son of a ditch digger, three-term governor and never quite presidential candidate -- was boiling mad. He rejected a seat on the United States Supreme Court, he has said, because he feared it would be the equivalent of having his tongue cut out. He wanted to speak out freely on the issues.
docs.abstract: Former New York Gov Mario Cuomo discusses his life now, at age 68, as big-ticket Manhattan attorney, political commentator, children's book author and dedicated basketball player; interview; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Congress tonight finished its work for the year and approved a huge spending bill after President Clinton reached agreement with a powerful Alaska senator on a compromise to protect an endangered species of sea lion. The House passed the omnibus spending bill by a vote of 292 to 60, and the Senate approved it by voice vote. This cleared the way for final adjournment of the 106th Congress, which began nearly two years ago with the Senate impeachment trial of President Clinton.

headline.main: Congress Finishes Its Work By Approving Spending Bill

docs.abstract: House and Senate pass $450 billion omnibus spending bill, clearing way for final adjournment of 106th Congress; passage closes long-running budget battle between Pres Bill Clinton and Congress; Clinton lauds budget as fiscally responsible, saying it will pay down national debt and make vital investments in nation's future (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was sheer woman power secretary power, actually -- that got Marcia D. Greenberger the job as the first full-time women's rights lawyer in Washington. Back in the early 1970's, the headiest days of the women's movement, the secretaries at the Center for Law and Social Policy went to the male lawyers who founded the group and presented a list of demands: They did not want to serve coffee anymore. They wanted raises. They wanted the center to start a women's rights project. And they wanted a female lawyer hired for it. Enter Ms. Greenberger, two years out of the University of Pennsylvania law school and working, with something less than passion, as a tax lawyer in a private firm.

headline.main: Guiding the Battles of the Women's Rights Movement

docs.lead_paragraph: If President-elect George W. Bush's central message on Wednesday night was to promote healing and conciliation, the tonic he offered was bipartisanship, Texas-style. ''Here, in a place where Democrats have the majority,'' Mr. Bush said from the podium of the Texas House of Representatives, ''Republicans and Democrats have worked together to do what is right for the people we represent.''

headline.main: Texas's Bipartisanship May Differ From Capital's

docs.abstract: Pres-elect George W Bush's acceptance speech before Texas Legislature, vowing to promote healing and conciliation, advanced Texas-style notion of bipartisanship; tenor of Texas Capitol hardly resembles divisiveness in Congress, where gridlock over major issues exposes deep rifts between parties; many Republicans and Democrats in State Legislature are fairly similar in ideology and are bound by shared conservatism centering on limited government and low taxes; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK QUEENS: SCHOOL BOARD BACKS SCOUTS -- In a largely symbolic act of defiance against Chancellor Harold O. Levy, a Queens school board adopted a resolution last night supporting the Boy Scouts. Community School Board 24 voted 6 to 1 to continue to sponsor Scout activities, two weeks after Mr. Levy barred the Scouts during school hours because of their policy against gay troop leaders. In a half-hour debate before the vote, Walter Sanchez, a Scout leader in Middle Village, praised the board for its courage in challenging the chancellor, while Daniel Dromm, a gay teacher at Public School 199, said the board cared more about politics than children. Board members conceded that they had little authority to enforce the resolution. Anemona Hartocollis (NYT)
